head.title: Senator Sets Priorities for Tobacco Legislation

hedline.hl1: Senator Sets Priorities for Tobacco Legislation

abstract.p: Sen John McCain, pivotal Senator on tobacco issue, says several issues must be resolved before legislation can go forward such as extent of tobacco companies' protection from lawsuits and how Food and Drug Administration will regulate tobacco (M)

After a session that illuminated sharp disagreements, Senator John McCain, the pivotal Senator on the tobacco issue, said today that he could now separate the central questions from the more secondary ones.
In the first category, issues that must be resolved before legislation can go forward, Mr. McCain, an Arizona Republican, listed these topics:
*The extent of tobacco companies' protection from lawsuits.
*How the Food and Drug Administration would regulate tobacco.
*The goals for the reduction in youth smoking and the fines that would be imposed on cigarette manufacturers if the goals were not met.
*How much the price of a pack of cigarettes would be increased.

On the more peripheral issues, Mr. McCain listed such questions as the size of lawyers' fees, the future of the Government's tobacco-price support program and the way the money raised from cigarette manufacturers would be distributed and spent.

There are major disputes over these secondary matters, Mr. McCain said in an interview after a hearing of the Commerce Committee, of which he is chairman, but the fate of the legislation does not hinge on their resolution.

While the senators debated tobacco issues today, new figures showed that tobacco interests have been spending an extraordinary amount, more than $75 million over the last two years, lobbying Congress and the Federal agencies.

House Democrats led by Representatives Vic Fazio and Henry A. Waxman, both of California, offered tough anti-smoking legislation that included a big price increase on cigarettes and no industry protection against lawsuits except for those filed by Federal, state and local governments. The bill is a companion to legislation proposed by Senator Kent Conrad, Democrat of North Dakota.

Under the agreement that tobacco companies reached last June with 40 state attorneys general, the industry would be given immunity from further government lawsuits and private class-action suits and considerable protection against other legal claims.
In return, the cigarette makers would restrain their advertising and marketing and pay a large sum to settle punitive damage claims based on past industry practices.
